e4: I would recommend maintaining the current policy or finding a middle ground that balances transparency with the needs of retail investors. While changing to an unbiased policy might please sophisticated investors and reduce legal liability, it could unfairly burden smaller investors who have adjusted their expectations accordingly over time. A more nuanced approach might involve educating retail investors about the change in policy or providing transition guidance to minimize potential disruptions.
e5: A reporting policy is ethical when it prioritizes transparency, accuracy, and fairness. It should avoid misleading or unfairly benefiting specific groups of stakeholders. In this context, an ideal policy would provide clear and consistent guidance to all investors, including retail and sophisticated ones, while avoiding unfair advantages or disadvantages. Considerations like accountability, compliance with regulations, and stakeholder communication are also essential in creating a responsible reporting policy that maintains trust and ensures long-term sustainability.
e6: Yes, I would ask the management team about their plans to communicate this change to retail investors and how they will ensure that sophisticated investors do not exploit the new policy, while also protecting the interests of smaller investors.
